etymology.description: Depiction of a silk thread; compare 糸.
etymology.interpretation: Originally a sketch of a thin silk strand, later stylized into the two hooked strokes seen today. By association with something slender and slight, it extended to meanings like tiny and, in family ranking, the youngest.

examples.chinese: 报数时，用“幺”代替“一”，以免混淆。(報數時，用「幺」代替「一」，以免混淆。)
examples.pinyin: Bàoshù shí, yòng “yāo” dàitì “yī”, yǐmiǎn hùnxiáo.
examples.english: When reporting numbers, use “yāo” instead of “yī” to avoid confusion.

examples.chinese: 他是家里的老幺。(他是家裡的老幺。)
examples.english: He is the youngest in the family.

examples.chinese: 在麻将里，幺九指一和九。(在麻將裡，幺九指一和九。)
examples.pinyin: Zài májiàng lǐ, yāojiǔ zhǐ yī hé jiǔ.
examples.english: In mahjong, yaojiu refers to the tiles one and nine.
